Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Heterogeneous layers?
Input.posts:
All the neural networks i have seen before were using homogeneous layers with respect the activation function. Is there any theoretical reason for that?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
No. Just a practical reason.
Instructor's post : No. Just a practical reason.
Upvotes:
0

Input.threadtitle: Objective function = loss function??
Input.posts:
are objective function and loss function same thing or different?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
More or less. The only ambiguity is whether we're trying to maximize or minimize. 'loss function' makes very explicit that we're minimizing it. 'objective function' leaves that a little more ambiguous. That's my interpretation, anyway. Others might have different interpretations of these phrases.
Instructor's post : More or less. The only ambiguity is whether we're trying to maximize or minimize. 'loss function' makes very explicit that we're minimizing it. 'objective function' leaves that a little more ambiguous. That's my interpretation, anyway. Others might have different interpretations of these phrases.

0

Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-05-T1.1

Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Lecture 15f RBMs behave like Contractive autoencoders?
Input.posts:
First thanks Prof. Hinton for this amazing course :) In lecture 15f, when mentioned Contractive autoencoders, Hinton said RBMs behave like it. How? I mean how the RBM can make the active set sparse. Is the CD algorithm make it? I am very interesting in autoencoders :) I think there will be more relationship between RBM and autoencoders. They are too similar but from totally different point of view.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
RBMs are ideally trained with a meta-algorithm (or estimator if you're in statistics) called maximum likelihood. There are alternatives, among them is one called score matching which can be shown to be a special case of contrastive divergence. If you apply score matching to an RBM (with Gaussian visible units) then the cost function turns out to basically be the same as the cost function for a contractive auto-encoder where the contraction is on the reconstruction. Denoising auto-encoders also fit into this framework. In general, contractive auto-encoders expand on these ideas in directions that break the equivalence to RBMs (e.g., putting the contraction term on the hidden activations), but they are still quite similar. I'm skipping a lot of details here, but that's the general picture.
Instructor's post : RBMs are ideally trained with a meta-algorithm (or estimator if you're in statistics) called maximum likelihood. There are alternatives, among them is one called score matching which can be shown to be a special case of contrastive divergence. If you apply score matching to an RBM (with Gaussian visible units) then the cost function turns out to basically be the same as the cost function for a contractive auto-encoder where the contraction is on the reconstruction. Denoising auto-encoders also fit into this framework. In general, contractive auto-encoders expand on these ideas in directions that break the equivalence to RBMs (e.g., putting the contraction term on the hidden activations), but they are still quite similar. I'm skipping a lot of details here, but that's the general picture.

If you apply score matching to an RBM (with Gaussian visible units) then the cost function turns out to basically be the same as the cost function for a contractive auto-encoder where the contraction is on the reconstruction. Denoising auto-encoders also fit into this framework. In general, contractive auto-encoders expand on these ideas in directions that break the equivalence to RBMs (e.g., putting the contraction term on the hidden activations), but they are still quite similar. I'm skipping a lot of details here, but that's the general picture.
Upvotes:
2

They are too similar but from totally different point of view.

Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Lecture 13b - the probability of orphan nodes
Input.posts:
In working through the math of the sigmoid belief networks, the point is made that for orphan nodes, p(s_i=1) simplifies to the sigmoid of the bias, since that node has no parents. If there is no bias, then the probability for the state of the orphan node becomes 1 / (1 + exp(0)) = 1/2. Intuitively, this makes sense for a node with no bias, but it's apparent from some of the lecture 13 quiz questions - 5 and 6 in particular, that I'm missing something. If the h2 node is considered an orphan, then p(h2=1) = p(h2=0) = 1/2, and the answer becomes very simple, which I think is incorrect. I've looked all over, but can't seem to see where I'm going wrong.
Upvotes:
2
It is correct that p(h2=0) = 1/2 and p(h2=1) = 1/2. However this is only a small part of the solution to the quiz questions, so your misunderstanding must at the next step P(v, h1, h2) = P(h1, h2) . P(v | h1, h2) Knowing what you know, you are part way to calculating P(h1, h2). After you calculate P(v, h1, h2) for (v1=1, h1=0, h2=0) and (v1=1, h1=0, h2=1) , you have all the pieces needed to find P(h2=1 | v=1, h1=0)
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
$$P(h_2=1)$$ is 1/2 indeed, but the probability **conditional** on the state of some visible units is not that simple.
Instructor's post : $$P(h_2=1)$$ is 1/2 indeed, but the probability **conditional** on the state of some visible units is not that simple.
Upvotes:
0
